author: By Astead W. Herndon and Richard Fausset
title: Early Voting Numbers in Georgia Senate Races Put G.O.P. on Edge
description: While polls suggest that the state’s crucial runoff elections are up for grabs, Republicans have grown worried about strong turnout in Democratic areas and mixed messages from President Trump.
content: MACON, Ga. — Senator Kelly Loeffler issued a now-familiar warning during a campaign event on Wednesday in Bibb County: If Democrats win the Georgia Senate runoff elections, there will be little left to stem a rising tide of extremist socialism in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Parliament Approves Post-Brexit Trade Deal
description: After the House of Commons overwhelmingly endorsed the 1,200-page agreement, the House of Lords also voted in favor of British ratification.
content: LONDON — Approval of a trade deal between Britain and the European Union was hurried through the British Parliament in just a day on Wednesday, a decisive but rushed conclusion to a long Brexit story that has divided Britons and convulsed their politics for more than four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Stimulus, Virus Variant, Georgia: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: McConnell Blocks Vote on $2,000 Checks Despite G.O.P. Pressure
description: Senator Mitch McConnell instead provided vague assurances that the Senate would “begin the process” of discussing the checks and two other issues that the president demanded lawmakers address.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell blocked an attempt by Democrats on Tuesday to hold an immediate vote on increasing stimulus checks to $2,000 from $600, leaving the fate of the measure unclear as President Trump continued to demand the larger payouts and more Republicans publicly endorsed the idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Which Digital Thermometer Is Best?
description: You asked, and Wirecutter has suggestions.
content: Good morning. I was pretty fierce in this space a few days ago, arguing that you need to use a digital thermometer if you want to cook a roast to the state you desire. The internal temperature of your particular cut of meat is the only reliable indicator of its “doneness.” Reliance on the minutes-per-pound at a particular oven temperature is a fool’s errand, dooming cooks either to undercook or overcook their meals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Discovery of Virus Variant in Colorado and California Alarms Scientists
description: A more contagious version of the coronavirus may alter the course of the pandemic in the United States, researchers said.
content: A contagious variant of the coronavirus spreading through Britain has left that nation grappling with new lockdowns, curtailed air travel and a surge in infections. Now it has appeared in Colorado and California, threatening to complicate what had seemed a hopeful, if halting, path to recovery from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Thomas and Monique Smith
title: How to Reassure Black Americans That the Vaccine Is Safe
description: After centuries of mistreatment, many African-Americans are wary of the Covid-19 shot. A public health campaign could help rebuild trust.
content: Many Black Americans say they are wary of taking the coronavirus vaccine, the logical result of centuries of abuse and exploitation by the United States health care system. We empathize with the patient who told one of us, “Baby, I just don’t trust vaccines,” and with our friends and family who say they are “just going to wait.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Cho
title: A 12-Year-Old’s Letter to Her Post-Pandemic Self
description: How will you retain gratitude for the return to normal life? “I’ve come from 2020 to remind you not to forget,” my daughter wrote to her future self.
content: My 12-year-old daughter, Audrey, told me recently on one of our many walks around the neighborhood that she would never forget this pandemic, and that she never wanted to take for granted having friends over, visiting extended family or hugging her grandparents again. She wondered, though, whether people would really live with new appreciation. Over time, would we all forget? Would a hug or a handshake become commonplace again?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Sale of Arctic Drilling Leases Draws an Unusual Taker. It May Be the Only One.
description: With a deadline looming and weak interest from oil companies, the state of Alaska may step in and buy leases in the hope of reassigning them later. Some analysts saw that as a long shot.
content: After a three-year push by the Trump administration to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil drilling — an effort that culminated in a rush to sell leases before the White House changes hands — in the end the only taker may be the state of Alaska itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: ‘Let’s Talk About “Personal Responsibility”’: A Year of Tough Conversations in the Comments
description: Opinion writers reflect on what readers had to say in 2020.
content: This has been a tumultuous 12 months, a harrowing ride through the pandemic and elections, racial injustices and civic turmoil. Through it all, in your comments, you’ve shared your fears, frustrations and anger, but also hope, humor and much wisdom. In the process, you helped document this extraordinary year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Bonisteel
title: The Most-Read Food Stories of 2020
description: Readers turned to the Food section for advice on quarantine cooking, expiration dates and comfort food — lots of comfort food.
content: Decades from now, when cultural historians sift through the social media posts of 2020, they will tell the pandemic stories of savvy chefs and restaurateurs forced to pivot to meal kits, corner markets and sidewalk cafes as their industry collapsed, seemingly overnight. These historians will note the panic shopping of early March, as Americans rushed to buy N95 masks, toilet paper and Clorox wipes, along with whatever pantry staples they could find, 20-pound bags of flour and industrial-size bricks of active dry yeast included.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Dera Menra Sijabat
title: Indonesia Disbands Radical Islamic Group Over Charges of Violence
description: The government dissolved the Islamic Defenders Front over charges that its members committed terrorism. Its leader is already under arrest.
content: BANGKOK — The hard-line Islamic Defenders Front was outlawed by the Indonesian government on Wednesday and ordered to cease all activities less than two months after its fiery leader, Rizieq Shihab, returned from self-imposed exile and pledged to lead a “moral revolution.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 25 Days That Changed the World: How Covid-19 Slipped China’s Grasp
description: Beijing acted against the coronavirus with stunning force, as its official narratives recount. But not before a political logjam had allowed a local outbreak to kindle a global pandemic.
content: The most famous doctor in China was on an urgent mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: How the Networks Will Fill Airtime on a Quiet New Year’s Eve
description: In a typical year, shots of raucous parties from around the world dominate news programming. This year, the networks had to get more creative.
content: What becomes of Times Square when you take away hundreds of thousands of cheering, shivering New Year’s Eve revelers?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Reinstein
title: Watch 8 Classic TV Episodes About New Year’s Eves Gone Awry
description: Are your plans feeling particularly lackluster this year? Take heart: These are a reminder that Dec. 31 isn’t always what it’s cracked up to be.
content: At long last, we’ve arrived to the sole silver lining of the 2020 holiday season: a built-in excuse to stay home on Dec. 31 and feel good about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel J. Wakin
title: As the Pandemic Took Lives, It Also Stole Hopes
description: Many of Covid-19’s victims had been entering new chapters in their lives: fatherhood, a career, freedom, citizenship.
content: The scythe of Covid-19 was unsparing as it devastated one nation after another, claiming all  types of people in a death toll now heading toward 2 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Pandemic Worsens Poverty’s Ills for Families
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 30, 2020.
content: “For African-Americans in this country, it’s almost a birthright to be resilient. We’ve learned those skills, sometimes at 4 years old. Now it’s about surviving.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Iran Approves Payments for Shooting Down Ukraine Airliner
description: Tehran said it will pay $150,000 to the family of each victim, but Ukraine said it expects more, including a thorough investigation.
content: Iran’s Cabinet on Wednesday allocated $150,000 for the families of each of the 176 people killed when Iranian forces shot down a Ukrainian airliner in January, the official IRNA news agency reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: Let There Be Light, and Art, in the Moynihan Train Hall
description: The expansion of Penn Station’s concourse has an acre of glass that lets the sun pour down, and installations by Kehinde Wiley, Stan Douglas and Elmgreen & Dragset. Here’s a first look.
content: Sunlight is not typically associated with the dingy basement vibe that envelops commuters passing through Penn Station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: A ‘Frankenstein’ That Never Lived
description: On Jan. 4, 1981, the effects-heavy production opened and closed on the same night. Forty years later, the creators revisit a very expensive Broadway flop.
content: When the curtain went up at the Palace Theater on Jan. 4, 1981, the expectations — and the stakes — were high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Wounds on Brown Pelicans in California Raise Fears of Animal Cruelty
description: In a little over a year, five birds have been treated by International Bird Rescue with severe slashes on their pouches that the organization believes were intentionally inflicted.
content: The first bird appeared in September 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Erasmus, Covid-19, Croatia: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdullah Alaoudh
title: Saudi Arabia Is Slowly Killing My Father
description: President-elect Joe Biden must push the country to release its political prisoners.
content: On Monday, a court in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, sentenced Loujain al-Hathloul, the Saudi activist, to five years and eight months in prison. Ms. al-Hathloul, who campaigned for the right of women to drive, was convicted of “trying to harm national security” and advancing “a foreign agenda.” She has already been in prison for two and a half years. A combination of time served and partial sentence suspension could lead to her release in a month or so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: She Mocked Men’s Bluster. Then Came the Complaints.
description: A stand-up comedian in China suggested that some men had an unwarranted confidence. An attempt to censor her followed.
content: HONG KONG — Yang Li, a comedian, tells jokes about men and their egos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: The Hilaria Baldwin Story: ‘I’m Living My Life’
description: Accused of a “decade long grift where she impersonates a Spanish person,” the entrepreneur and spouse of Alec Baldwin talks about Spain, Boston, her children, Instagram and more.
content: The first signs that Hilaria Baldwin’s life was going seriously off the rails came from the same place where she usually derives her sense of control. “I started seeing comments on my Instagram,” she said in an interview Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Shimabukuro
title: What’s on the Horizon for the Climate Desk
description: After a year when climate-related disasters seemed to become the norm, the team will be monitoring a 2021 that is pivotal for the world.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Protesters Who Fled by Boat Are Sentenced to Prison in China
description: The pro-democracy activists, who hoped to reach Taiwan, were caught by the Chinese Coast Guard and tried in the mainland’s opaque criminal justice system.
content: HONG KONG — A group of Hong Kong protesters who were arrested by the Chinese authorities while fleeing the city by speedboat were sentenced by a mainland court to between seven months and three years in prison on Wednesday, in the Chinese Communist Party’s latest offensive against pro-democracy activists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry Kennedy Meltzer
title: Vaccines Are Safe, No Matter What Bobby Kennedy Says
description: I love my uncle. But when it comes to vaccines, he is wrong.
content: My hospital, along with hundreds of others across the country, recently began to administer the first Covid-19 vaccines. My social media feed is filled with pictures of friends and colleagues, sleeves rolled up, writing about how much this vaccination means to them. In an otherwise dark year, it’s a moment of hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Amy Qin
title: China Approves Covid-19 Vaccine as It Moves to Inoculate Millions
description: Sinopharm, a state-controlled company, said its candidate had a 79 percent efficacy rate in interim late-stage trials. But crucial questions remained unanswered.
content: The Chinese government said on Thursday that it had approved a homegrown coronavirus vaccine after an early analysis of clinical trial results showed that it was effective. The announcements sent a positive signal for the global rollout of Chinese vaccines but lacked crucial details.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Howard J. Rubenstein, Public Relations Impresario, Dies at 88
description: He polished the tarnished images of the rich, the famous and the flawed, with clients that included Donald J. Trump, Rupert Murdoch and George M. Steinbrenner.
content: Howard J. Rubenstein, who softened life’s blows and polished the tarnished images of the rich, the famous and the flawed for more than 65 years  in becoming New York’s pre-eminent public relations impresario, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Shimabukuro and Claire O'Neill
title: Looking ahead to 2021
description: Also this week: Your New Year’s climate resolutions
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The last week of 2020.
description: Suggestions for the end of the year.
content: Welcome. It’s the last week of the year, a time when many of us might normally be visiting with family and friends. This year has required some reconfiguring of holiday plans: You might be staying inside, with your usual brood or on your own; you might be working or looking for work; busy or looking for diversion. If you find yourself with the time and inclination to do some reading, there are a bunch of culture and lifestyle stories in The Times that you should check out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: The 2020 Good Tech Awards
description: This year, technology firms big and small stepped up to help with the Covid-19 pandemic and other thorny challenges.
content: Some years, I have to dig deep to come up with worthy honorees for the Good Tech Awards, my annual column that honors what I consider the most humane and altruistic tech projects of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Brexit, Lockdown and a Vaccine: A Head-Spinning Day of Change in U.K.
description: Britain put millions more people under severe virus restrictions and approved a new vaccine, while Parliament approved a post-Brexit trade deal with the European Union.
content: LONDON — Just before 3 p.m. on Wednesday, British lawmakers voted to ratify the Brexit trade agreement with the European Union, drawing a symbolic end to a debate that has sundered the country for more than four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Horn, Elysa Gardner and Giovanni Russonello
title: How to Stream New Year’s Eve: 25 Shows From Pop, Jazz and Beyond
description: It isn’t too late to make (cheap!) plans to welcome 2021 with music. A host of concerts will be streaming around the globe and major stars will take the stage on TV.
content: THE AVETT BROTHERS If your appetite for sentimentality hasn’t been sated by holiday films, this may be the livestream for you. In their strummy folk-rock vernacular and tidy close harmonies, the brothers Scott and Seth Avett sing earnest songs about love and family. A slew of special guests — including Willie Nelson, Brandi Carlile, Norah Jones and Loudon Wainwright III — will bolster the star power of this New Year’s Eve performance (the 17th edition of an annual Avett tradition). At 8 p.m. Eastern, nugs.tv. Tickets start at $40. (Olivia Horn)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Myung-Ok Lee
title: 4 Young Adult Crossover Novels
description: The latest fiction from Nic Stone, Elizabeth Wein, David Yoon and Arvin Ahmadi.
content: DEAR JUSTYCEBy Nic Stone288 pp. Crown. $18.99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Don’t Let the Games Begin
description: College athletics can teach the right lesson by insisting that public health is more important than sports.
content: Look no further than the storied Rose Bowl game to understand the National Collegiate Athletic Association’s disingenuous and perilous posturing about the sanctity of its athletics programs while the coronavirus has ravaged the country and college campuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Test Your 2020 Knowledge
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: It’s been an eventful year, to say the least. David Leonhardt, who usually writes this newsletter, has created a quiz that tests your knowledge of the year’s biggest stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What We Learned About California in 2020
description: Wednesday: The year’s almost over. It’s been illuminating.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Contract Killers
description: Kate Hawkins creates a virtual community of sorts.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Among the rising stars in the New York Times crossworld, Kate Hawkins is a veritable constellation. Her Times debut was in August, and this puzzle is already her third to appear here. Like a cut-glass candy dish this time of year, it’s piled high with colorful treats — trivia from pop culture, botany, the Olympics, animated rodents. You know the drill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Who Replaces Me?’: An Update
description: A Black police officer in Flint, Mich., reflects on what it now means to be part of the force in his hometown.
content: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Alaska Airlines Clamps Down on Emotional Support Animals on Flights
description: The airline says it will permit service dogs only, following a move by the U.S. Department of Transportation to reclassify the types of service animals allowed on flights.
content: If you’re flying on Alaska Airlines starting in mid-January, don’t plan on boarding with your support pig or miniature horse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Sleep Better in the New Year
description: Advice from Well on how to get more and sounder sleep in 2021.
content: For many, 2020 was a year that provided lots of worries that kept us tossing and turning at night. Tara Parker-Pope’s guide, How to Get a Better Night’s Sleep, is packed with advice:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: How Argentina Bucked Tradition in Latin America and Legalized Abortion
description: The region, where Roman Catholic and evangelical churches hold sway, has long been unfriendly territory for abortion rights advocates. Argentina in 2020, though, offered a different landscape.
content: Latin America has long been hostile terrain for abortion rights advocates, even in recent decades as legal abortion became accessible in most of Europe, North America and other parts of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Cavendish and Rick Rojas
title: Nashville Suspect’s Girlfriend Told Police Last Year That He Was Making Bombs
description: Officers visited the home of Anthony Warner after his girlfriend said he was producing explosives in his R.V., according to a police report. They said then that there was no evidence of a crime.
content: NASHVILLE — A girlfriend of the man who the authorities say set off a bomb in downtown Nashville on Christmas had called police officers to his home last year, claiming that he had been making bombs in the R.V. parked there, according to a police incident report.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Judge John Hodgman on Calling Yourself Middle-Aged
description: Is 32 the new 45?
content: Blake writes: My mother thinks I’m too young to call myself middle-aged. I’m 32, well into the middle range of the average American male life span. My wife and I are expecting our second child. May I say I’m middle-aged?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Alone in a Fancy Hotel Bathroom
description: Parents’ solo-vacation fantasies, hopefully realized in 2021.
content: When I’m having trouble falling asleep, I think about a paddle boat ride I took in 2010. My husband and I were on our honeymoon, staying at a hotel in Portugal that was right on the bay. I have a visceral memory of raising my face to the sun, lazily paddling around while the sea breeze gently flowed around me. I recall that moment when I’m tossing and turning in these pandemic times; I felt so relaxed and free then … because I didn’t have kids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein
title: The ‘Resistance’ Formed Because of Trump, With an Assist From Jon Ossoff
description: Mr. Ossoff’s 2017 special election was the first campaign Democrats had to focus on, after the shock of President Trump’s win. He lost, but the organizations formed around that race kept growing.
content: In early 2017, Angelika Kausche was frustrated, demoralized and looking for somewhere — or someone — to help her channel the rage she had recently expressed at the Women’s March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: Quarterback Keeper? Jets, Browns and Bears Face Contract Decisions
description: Sam Darnold, Baker Mayfield and Mitchell Trubisky have all been marginally impressive at times. But is that enough for their teams to sign them to salary-cap-straining contracts?
content: The most pivotal decision an N.F.L. team must make is often not drafting the right quarterback but determining the right thing to do with the quarterback it drafted a few years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: China approves one of its coronavirus vaccines.
content: The Chinese government said on Thursday that it had approved a homegrown coronavirus vaccine after an early analysis of clinical trial results showed that it was effective. The announcements sent a positive signal for the global rollout of Chinese vaccines but lacked crucial details.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saeed Al-Batati and Vivian Yee
title: Yemen Airport Is Attacked as New Government Arrives
description: The attack occurred just as a plane carrying several cabinet officials landed. The cabinet’s formation was supposed to be a step toward resolving Yemen’s civil war.
content: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — An attack on an airport in Aden, Yemen, killed at least 20 civilians and wounded dozens more on Wednesday just as a plane carrying members of the country’s newly formed government cabinet was arriving, the Yemeni health minister’s office said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Pieces of a Woman’ Review: A Raw, Ragged Study of a Loss
description: Vanessa Kirby gives an intensely physical performance as a woman whose life and marriage are upended by the death of a child.
content: There are two remarkable scenes in “Pieces of a Woman,” though the first — an almost 30-minute, largely unbroken opening shot of a home birth — seems set to divert critical attention from the second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: National Gallery of Art Acquires 40 Works by Black Southern Artists
description: The acquisition adds paintings, quilts and sculptures by more than 20 African-American artists, many of them self-taught, into the collection.
content: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has announced the acquisition of 40 works from the Souls Grown Deep Foundation, a nonprofit organization that for the last decade has dedicated itself to promoting the contributions of African-American artists from the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jolie Kerr
title: Andy Cohen Had a Year
description: Bravo’s main man bids adieu to what may have been the twenty-twentiest 2020 ever.
content: In February, the Bravo host and executive producer Andy Cohen sent his beagle, Wacha, to live with his animal trainer in Connecticut. Experts said Wacha needed to be rehomed for his safety and that of Mr. Cohen’s one-year-old son, Benjamin. “It truly was so traumatic, and so upsetting.” Mr. Cohen said recently. “I thought, ‘Wow, 2020 really stinks. Like, it could never, ever get worse than this.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Schoenfeld
title: Was the College Football Season Worth It?
description: It brought joy — and revenue. But the full cost will never be tallied.
content: On a Friday evening in early August, Kevin Warren logged in to a video call with medical officials from athletic departments around the Big Ten. By then, Warren had been the commissioner of the conference for eight months. Those months had not gone according to plan. He had come from the N.F.L., where his most recent job was chief operating officer for the Minnesota Vikings. The first African-American commissioner of a major college conference, he had almost no experience in college sports. He was regarded as an outsider, a perception he shared. To help overcome that, Warren had intended to hold a town-hall meeting on each of the 14 Big Ten campuses during his first year as commissioner. The conference fielded 350 teams across 28 sports, and Warren planned to see every one of them in action. When the pandemic hit in early March, he had seen 105 teams play and hosted three town halls. He still barely knew the university presidents and chancellors, who hired him, or the athletic directors. Unlike his predecessor, Jim Delany, whose tenure as commissioner lasted three decades, Warren had no particular friends or allies among either group. And now he faced one of the most consequential decisions in conference history: Should the Big Ten play football in 2020?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Gillian Friedman
title: Stimulus Money Should Have Gone to the Jobless, Economists Say
description: While lawmakers debate increasing the payments to $2,000, most Americans are expected to save, not spend, their $600 checks.
content: Galen Gilbert knows just what he will do with the check he gets from Washington as part of the pandemic relief package, whatever the amount: put it in the bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Cuttlefish Took Something Like a Marshmallow Test. Many Passed.
description: It turns out that camouflage isn’t the only talent these cephalopods have.
content: Zipping through water like shimmering arrowheads, cuttlefish are swift, sure hunters — death on eight limbs and two waving tentacles for small creatures in their vicinity. They morph to match the landscape, shifting between a variety of hues and even textures, using tiny structures that expand and contract beneath their skin. They even seem to have depth perception, researchers using tiny 3-D vision glasses found, placing them apart from octopuses and squids. And their accuracy at striking prey is remarkable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: The Risks of the Covid Vaccine, in Context
description: We should expect some people to experience side effects. The shot is still safer than the disease.
content: At this point, most of us have heard about allergic reactions to Covid-19 vaccines: the doctor in Boston who had to administer his EpiPen, the hospital worker in Alaska who had trouble breathing. But it’s not at all surprising that allergic reactions happen. What matters most is the severity and the rate at which they occur. And for the Covid vaccines, there’s no doubt that the value of vaccination outweighs the risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Orovic and Marc Santora
title: As Aftershocks Rattle Croatia, Quake Recovery Is Slow and Perilous
description: Tens of thousands of people have been left homeless after the powerful 6.4 magnitude earthquake that rocked central Croatia, killing seven and injuring dozens.
content: ZADAR, Croatia — After working through the night combing through the ruins of fallen buildings for survivors of a powerful 6.4 magnitude earthquake that rocked central Croatia, the search and rescue operation shifted gears on Wednesday to focus on helping tens of thousands of people left homeless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Dawn Wells, Mary Ann on ‘Gilligan’s Island,’ Dies at 82
description: Her character on the ’60s sitcom radiated all-American wholesomeness and youthful charm. After her TV career cooled, she focused on theater acting.
content: Dawn Wells, the actress who radiated all-American wholesomeness, Midwestern practicality and a youthful naïve charm as the character Mary Ann on the hit 1960s sitcom “Gilligan’s Island,” died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Los Angeles. She was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $3 Million Homes in Florida, New York and Virginia
description: A three-bedroom home with a guest cottage in Key West, an 18th-century Dutch Colonial in Brooklyn and a Federal-style townhouse in Alexandria.
content: This white clapboard house, at the corner of Southard and William Streets in the heart of Old Town, is being sold with all of its furnishings, down to the pots and pans. It is on Solares Hill, the highest point on Key West, and the structure itself is elevated, reducing the cost of flood insurance. City records date the main building to 1928 and the cottage to 1933, but they could well be older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Frakt
title: What Can Be Learned From Differing Rates of Suicide Among Groups
description: White Americans have higher rates than most other racial and ethnic groups.
content: U.S. suicide rates vary widely across racial and ethnic groups in ways that can upend expectations. The explanations may suggest avenues for prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: New Train Hall Opens at Penn Station, Echoing Building’s Former Glory
description: The Moynihan Train Hall, with glass skylights and 92-foot-high ceilings, will open Jan. 1 as an area for Amtrak and Long Island Rail Road riders.
content: For more than half a century, New Yorkers have trudged through the crammed platforms, dark hallways and oppressively low ceilings of Pennsylvania Station, the busiest and perhaps most miserable train hub in North America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: Chicago Blackhawks’ Jonathan Toews Is Out Indefinitely Because of Illness
description: Toews, 32, the team captain, did not say what his condition was but said that it had left him “drained and lethargic.”
content: Jonathan Toews, the Chicago Blackhawks’ center and team captain, announced on Tuesday that he would not join the team when it begins training camp on Sunday and that he would be out indefinitely because of a medical condition. He did not say what the condition was, but he described its effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry and Sarah Blesener
title: This New Year’s Eve, Times Square Will Be Filled With Hope. But Not People.
description: Celebrations will be muted as 2020 finally comes to an end, but they will bring much-needed touches of grace.
content: Last New Year’s Eve, an undulating sea flooded Midtown Manhattan, rippling through the streets and establishments to lap against the peacocking George M. Cohan statue in Times Square. A million people strong, all kissing and cheering in the warm glow of 2020’s promise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: From a 1550s Pandemic, a Choral Work Still Casts Its Spell
description: We know remarkably little about John Sheppard and his “Media vita.” But it has become a cult favorite of early music.
content: “Media vita” starts low, rising as if from catacombs. The tenors begin, sounding the slow, steady chant that will occupy them for more than 20 minutes. Countertenors come in above them, also rising step by step. Then the highest line enters, then another, another, still another, until all six parts take flight — rich yet somehow fragile, even lonely, and full of fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: The Bruce Willis Journey From In Demand to On Demand
description: An assessment of the actor’s late-career B-movie filmography, including his most recent entry, “Breach.”
content: It’s hard to keep track of Bruce Willis’s filmography, especially since 2015. In recent years, the star’s IMDb page has swollen with a torrent of action productions that drown out the occasional ambitious work like “Motherless Brooklyn” or “Glass.” Mnemonics are useful to keep track of the banal titles: “Hard Kill” followed “First Kill”; “Trauma Center” takes place in … a trauma center. But really, anybody would be forgiven for mixing up “Reprisal” with “Marauders,” or “Acts of Violence” with Willis’s most recent paycheck, “Breach” (available in select theaters and on-demand, which is where most of these movies begin their careers).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: 5 Dance Picture Books
description: Children of all abilities glide from page to stage with the likes of American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet pros.
content: I WILL DANCEWritten by Nancy Bo FloodIllustrated by Julianna Swaney
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon Sends More B-52s to Middle East to Deter Iranian Attacks on U.S. Troops
description: The flights came a week after President Trump warned Tehran following rocket strikes on the U.S. Embassy in Iraq.
content: WASHINGTON — Two American B-52 bombers flew another show-of-force mission in the Persian Gulf on Wednesday, a week after President Trump warned Iran that he would hold it accountable “if one American is killed” in rocket attacks in Iraq that the administration and military officials blamed on Tehran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi and Ernesto Londoño
title: Argentina Legalizes Abortion, a Milestone in a Conservative Region
description: The Senate vote on Wednesday was a major victory for Latin America’s growing feminist movement, and its ripple effects are likely to be widespread.
content: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina on Wednesday became the largest nation in Latin America to legalize abortion, a landmark vote in a conservative region and a victory for a grass-roots movement that turned years of rallies into political power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: One Way to Avoid Other Guests? Book the Entire Hotel
description: For those who aren’t deterred by a bill in the thousands, if not tens of thousands, buyouts of entire hotels or resorts offer the amenities and services of a hotel and the privacy and control of a vacation rental.
content: When Jack Samenuk checked into Zabriskie House this week, there was no mystery about who he would encounter in the inn’s double parlor or wood-paneled dining room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Steven Lee Myers
title: China and E.U. Leaders Strike Investment Deal, but Political Hurdles Await
description: The agreement, which would roll back restrictions on investment, faces some opposition in Europe and objections from the Biden camp.
content: Chinese and European Union leaders agreed on Wednesday to make it easier for companies to operate on each other’s territory, a significant geopolitical victory for China when criticism of its human rights record and handling of the pandemic have left it increasingly isolated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Rebecca Robbins
title: U.K. Authorizes Covid-19 Vaccine From Oxford and AstraZeneca
description: Health officials hope to soon vaccinate up to two million people per week as the country’s hospitals are overwhelmed by cases of a new, more contagious coronavirus variant.
content: LONDON — Britain on Wednesday became the first country to give emergency authorization to the coronavirus vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford, clearing the path for a cheap and easy-to-store shot that much of the world will rely on to help end the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: How Cities Around the World Will Say Goodbye, at Long Last, to 2020
description: The year that seemed to drag on forever is finally coming to an end.
content: In most cities this New Year’s Eve, there will be no roaring crowds, no gatherings for fireworks shows and, let’s hope, no strangers kissing at midnight. But, after a year punctuated by disease, unemployment and racial unrest, people around the world, in different circumstances than usual, will still raise a glass and toast the start of 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: She’s Starring Opposite Tom Hanks. She’d Never Heard of Him.
description: Helena Zengel is a giggly, chatty 12-year-old, whose movie roles take her into psychological territory that even adults would find tough.
content: BERLIN — When the director Paul Greengrass was gearing up to make his new film, “News of the World,” about a Civil War veteran in 1870s Texas who escorts an orphaned girl to her relatives across the state, he was anticipating one major challenge. “This is the first film I made with a child actor at the heart of it,” he said recently by phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Joe Clark, Tough Principal at New Jersey High School, Dies at 82
description: Bullhorn in hand, he roamed the hallways as he imposed discipline, expelling “miscreants” and restoring order. Morgan Freeman portrayed him in the film “Lean on Me.”
content: Joe Clark, the imperious disciplinarian principal of a troubled New Jersey high school in the 1980s who gained fame for restoring order as he roamed its hallways with a bullhorn and sometimes a baseball bat, died on Tuesday at his home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: When Sports Made Us Happy in 2020
description: Sports were not a simple salve for the events of 2020, but they still provided some moments of joy, levity and shared humanity.
content: In a year in which Covid-19 caused more than 1.7 million deaths worldwide, sports competitions took place amid much debate over their necessity and the wisdom of their proceeding during a global health crisis. Did any good come from them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: U.S. Penalizes Venezuelan Officials Involved in Imprisoning 6 American Oil Executives
description: The so-called Citgo 6 were lured to Venezuela for a business meeting in 2017 and have been sentenced to prison on charges of corruption.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration imposed sanctions on Wednesday on two Venezuelan officials for their roles in sending six American oil executives to prison on corruption charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Ticketmaster Will Pay $10 Million to Put Songkick Criminal Case to Rest
description: The concert giant has agreed to pay the fine to resolve charges that it intruded into the computer system of one of its competitors.
content: Ticketmaster has agreed to pay a $10 million fine to resolve charges that it intruded into the computer system of one of its competitors, prosecutors said on Wednesday, ending a yearslong legal battle over claims that the company illegally interfered in the business of a ticketing start-up called Songkick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Colorado may have a second case of the more contagious virus variant.
description: The newly discovered, more contagious variant of the coronavirus — first seen in Britain — may have been found in a second person in Colorado, state officials said on Wednesday.
content: The newly discovered, more contagious variant of the coronavirus — first seen in Britain — may have been found in a second person in Colorado, state officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis
title: This Year Was a Disaster. We Hope the Sequel Is Better.
description: We streamed, we watched, we worried. We also wondered what the catastrophe called 2020 will mean for movies.
content: The end of December usually brings a flurry of big releases and a blizzard of Oscar speculation. But with the Academy Awards postponed and many theaters shuttered or half-empty, this movie year closes with a shiver of existential anxiety in Hollywood and beyond. In 2020, Netflix expanded its reach, and two of the surviving legacy studios — Warner Bros. and Disney — beefed up their streaming platforms, the latest sign of a shift in business strategy that is likely to outlast the pandemic. As 2021 approaches, our critics examine the film industry in crisis, and wonder what the future might hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: A Chinese coronavirus vaccine has proved effective, its maker said.
description: A Chinese pharmaceutical company on Wednesday said late-stage drug trials showed that one of its coronavirus vaccines was effective, delivering positive results that could pave the way for the global rollout of hundreds of millions of Chinese vaccine doses in the coming months.
content: A Chinese pharmaceutical company on Wednesday said late-stage drug trials showed that one of its coronavirus vaccines was effective, delivering positive results that could pave the way for the global rollout of hundreds of millions of Chinese vaccine doses in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 4 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: On view this week: Analia Saban’s subtly unique prints; Cate Giordano’s tableaus of Henry VIII’s bride; Kim Jones’s gritty assemblage-sculptures; and Harmony Hammond’s textile art.
content: A print, at least usually, isn’t finished when you pull the sheet off the lithograph stone or the copper plate. You have to sign the print, outside the plate mark, and then number it. So each identical print becomes unique outside the artwork’s borders — an antinomy that Analia Saban, an Argentine-artist based in Los Angeles, disturbs and amplifies in “This One,” her clever, subtly difficult recursive series of three black-and-white etchings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Young
title: I Miss Dap
description: In this year of losses, even the way we greet each other has changed.
content: It’s funny how, in the 10th month of Covid, some of the things I miss most are things I hadn’t thought were missable. I miss the barbershop, for instance, for reasons that would be obvious if you saw me. I used to make weekly trips, but I haven’t been since March. I feel as if I look like a mashup of Frederick Douglass and Chewbacca’s neck. I’m pining for the pomp and circumstance in the process of the cut, the ceremony of the barber raising and snapping the cape before smoothing it on me and fastening it around my neck, the sting and lovely stank of peroxide applied to my fresh hairline and newly speck-free neck. And then the big reveal — the moment when the artisan has finished and spins me in the chair to face the wall of mirrors and witness the masterwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The 2020 High School Yearbook of Donald J. Trump
description: The year’s best, worst and weirdest political players.
content: This year was a soul-crushing hellscape of a dumpster fire. For sanity’s sake, large chunks of it should be repressed as soon as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Michael Crowley
title: Hawley Answers Trump’s Call for Election Challenge
description: The Republican senator said he would object to certifying the Electoral College votes on Jan. 6, a move that is unlikely to alter President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
content: WASHINGTON — Josh Hawley became the first senator on Wednesday to take up President Trump’s demand that lawmakers challenge the results of the 2020 election, saying he would object to Congress’s certification of the Electoral College results on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Meet Bill Butler, the Godfather of Roller Disco
description: He brought dance music to the Empire Rollerdrome in Brooklyn, and taught generations of skaters how to roll, bounce and be jammas.
content: When Grace Jones was strutting around Studio 54 and Donna Summer records were playing at New York clubs, Empire Rollerdrome was hitting its stride in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Pierre Cardin: He Dressed Jane Jetson and Lady Gaga
description: Some observations on the influential designer who made futurism his watchword.
content: The Italian-born Frenchman Pierre Cardin’s surname was perhaps the first French word that many Americans could easily pronounce. People with no inkling of how to utter designer names like Givenchy, with its suppressed “g,” and the sibilant Gallic uptick at the end of Saint Laurent (let alone the impossible Yves) had little difficulty speaking the two syllables and hard consonants of Caar-dan. Lesson: If you plan to become a household name, pick one anybody can say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henrik Pryser Libell and Jenny Gross
title: Norway Landslide Injures 10 and Leaves 10 Missing
description: Several homes were destroyed in the landslide about 30 miles northeast of Oslo, the authorities said.
content: At least 10 people were injured and 10 people were missing on Wednesday after a landslide in a village about 30 miles northeast of Oslo that Prime Minister Erna Solberg of Norway said was one of the worst in the country’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alana Celii, Crista Chapman, Brent Lewis, Renee Melides and Brent Murray
title: When Business as Usual Was Turned Upside Down
description: A photo retrospective of how the pandemic changed the business world and ruptured the economy in 2020 — creating some winners and, tragically, too many losers.
content: The condition of the global economy and work force is easily measured in data: 82 million people around the world caught the coronavirus; 20 million in the United States were receiving unemployment benefits as of the end of November. But business is about more than data and the movement of capital and the pursuit of profit. This year, as the pandemic crippled the economy, photographers fanned out to document the virus’s toll on stores, restaurants and factories, and the workers they depend on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Indian State Ruled by Modi’s Party Bans Islamic Schools
description: More than 700 madrasas in Assam will be shut by April, the state’s education minister said. Opposition politicians called the move an attack on Muslims.
content: GUWAHATI, India — An Indian state ruled by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalist party on Wednesday passed a law abolishing all Islamic schools, saying they provided substandard education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: FAFSA’s Expected Family Contribution Is Going Away. Good Riddance.
description: The dollar figure that the federal financial aid form spits out has long left families confused and despondent. And then, there are those great expectations.
content: The Expected Family Contribution — a dreaded and confusing term for parents about to send their children to college — made little sense in the best of times. Now, it’s finally going away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: No Crowds, but Times Square Ball Drop Is Still Happening. Here’s How.
description: For the first time in decades, Times Square will be closed to the public on New Year’s Eve. Instead, dozens of frontline workers and their families will be honored with spots near the stage.
content: Every December, the eyes of the world are drawn to New York City, where a glittering crystal ball in Midtown Manhattan marks a communal chance for a new beginning. Hundreds of thousands assemble in person; millions more watch on television, pausing for a moment to join an annual ritual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: Robert Jones Jr. Is Son of Baldwin, and More
description: The writer’s debut novel, “The Prophets,” is the Black queer love story he longed to read.
content: In his 1985 essay “Here Be Dragons,” James Baldwin wrote: “At bottom, what I had learned was that the male desire for a male roams everywhere, avid, desperate, unimaginably lonely.” America’s attitudes toward sexuality, he added, are tragically, inextricably linked with its “ideals” of hyper-masculinity and racialized violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Numbers, Knowledge and Better Set Pieces: a View Into Soccer’s Future
description: F.C. Midtjylland’s search for competitive advantage has made it a place where ideas emerge. The problem is pretty soon everyone else has them, too.
content: Everything that happens at F.C. Midtjylland is quantified. Well, almost everything. Every game played by every one of the Danish soccer club’s teams produces data points in the thousands. Each training session, from the first team to the preteens in the academy, is recorded and codified and analyzed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in Costa Rica: A Slice of Oceanside Paradise for $1.1 Million
description: Beloved as a haven for tourists, Costa Rica’s housing market has been hit hard in this year of limited travel, with damaging effects rippling out to some, but not all, of its provinces.
content: This modern three-bedroom home sits on a hillside in Dominical, a beach town in Puntarenas province, on the southern Pacific coast of Costa Rica. Built in 2016, the 3,500-square-foot house is oriented to maximize ocean views, with sliding glass walls in every room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Times Insider Staff and Clay Hickson
title: 74 of Our Favorite Facts for 2020
description: Each day, our editors collect the most interesting, striking or delightful facts to appear in articles throughout the paper. Here are 74 from the past year that were the most revealing.
content: 1. Japan’s legal system has a 99 percent conviction rate.Carlos Ghosn, at Home but Waiting for the Next Move
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: Nearly a Century Later, We’re Still Reading — and Changing Our Minds About — Gatsby
description: Our critic considers why F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic inspires and withstands so much interpretation.
content: I’ve long held to the completely unsupported notion that a protagonist is simpler to write than a truly memorable supporting character. Sometimes just a silhouette — created with a few slashes of the pen, a few charismatic adjectives — seems the more unlikely accomplishment, born out of some surplus wit and energy, some surfeit of love for a fictional world that expresses itself in the desire to animate even its most minor participants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Warp Speed Officials Say Covid Vaccine Distribution Is Going Too Slowly
description: “We know that it should be better, and we’re working hard to make it better,” said Moncef Slaoui, a leader of the federal effort to accelerate vaccine development and distribution.
content: The distribution of vaccines in the United States has gotten off to a slower-than-expected start, federal health officials acknowledged in a news conference on Wednesday, though they also voiced confidence that the pace would accelerate in the coming weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: He Was Hospitalized for Covid-19. Then Hospitalized Again. And Again.
description: Significant numbers of coronavirus patients experience long-term symptoms that send them back to the hospital, taxing an already overburdened health system.
content: The routine things in Chris Long’s life used to include biking 30 miles three times a week and taking courses toward a Ph.D. in eight-week sessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Julius Randle Is Causing Something Rare: Excitement for the Knicks
description: After the Knicks’ seven consecutive losing seasons, Randle’s strong play is fueling a good start — and hope among fans.
content: You can count the games each N.B.A. team has played so far on a single hand. But since when has a small sample size ever stopped fans, especially Knicks fans, from being excited?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Rebecca Robbins
title: Biden Criticizes Trump on Vaccine Distribution and Pledges to Pick Up Pace
description: Three weeks from taking office, Joe Biden called vaccinating Americans “the greatest operational challenge we’ve ever faced as a nation” and offered a bleak assessment of the months ahead.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday criticized the speed of vaccine distribution under the Trump administration and promised to step up the pace when he takes office, while delivering a sober warning about the toll of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner
title: Jonathan Pollard, Spy for Israel, Gets Hero’s Welcome From Netanyahu: ‘You’re Home’
description: Mr. Pollard, who gave a range of classified documents to Israel starting in 1984, recently completed his parole. His case was a longstanding irritant to American-Israeli ties.
content: JERUSALEM — Jonathan J. Pollard, the American who served 30 years in prison for spying for Israel in a Cold War-era espionage case that had been a thorn in relations between the two allies, arrived in Israel early Wednesday to a carefully staged, if relatively subdued, hero’s welcome from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Rita Houston, WFUV D.J. Who Lifted Music Careers, Dies at 59
description: From a studio in the Bronx, she introduced listeners to artists from a wide range of genres. She was also a mentor to the stars, and a sometime-confidante.
content: Rita Houston, a big-hearted disc jockey with an intoxicating voice who championed artists like Brandi Carlile, Mumford & Sons, Adele, the Indigo Girls and Gomez at the widely followed WFUV-FM in the Bronx, died on Dec. 15 at her home in Valley Cottage, N.Y. She was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William McDonald
title: Death Transformed a Year, and What May Lie Ahead
description: As Covid-19 swept the world, the killing of George Floyd galvanized a racial justice movement, and the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg upended the makeup of the Supreme Court.
content: Death has rarely so shaped a year as it did in 2020. It swept the world riding the back of the coronavirus. It galvanized a Black Lives Matter movement across the United States and abroad, sending people of all colors into the streets to demand social justice. It altered the ideological makeup of the United States Supreme Court so decisively that the consequences of that shift will assuredly be felt for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Levin
title: Wood-Ridge, N.J.: Not Too Close to the City, or Too Far Away
description: This unpretentious suburb in Bergen County offers residents comfortable proximity to Manhattan and reasonably priced homes (some with skyline views).
content: In Wood-Ridge, N.J., residents are accustomed to clarifying where they live. “People don’t always get what you mean when you say ‘Wood-Ridge,’” said Melanie Nicoletti, a former Brooklynite. “Ridgewood and Woodbridge” — higher profile addresses in the Garden State — “they get.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How to Stay Connected and Fend Off Loneliness in the New Year
description: As we head into 2021, here is some advice from Well on how to replace loneliness with opportunities for connection.
content: This pandemic year has left too many of us feeling isolated and lonely. As we head into 2021, here is some advice from Well on how to replace loneliness with opportunities for connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Can 4 Seconds of Exercise Make a Difference?
description: Four seconds of intense intervals, repeated until they amount to a minute of total exertion, led to rapid improvements in strength and fitness in middle-aged and older adults.
content: In what is probably the definitive word on how little exercise we can get away with, a new study finds that a mere four seconds of intense intervals, repeated until they amount to about a minute of total exertion, lead to rapid and meaningful improvements in strength, fitness and general physical performance among middle-aged and older adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: From Kobe to LeBron: Tragedy and Triumph in the N.B.A.
description: A year that began with the deaths of two N.B.A. icons could not end soon enough, marked by heartache along the way but also small moments worth celebrating now.
content: The longest and possibly saddest year in pro basketball history is almost over. From this world that plays out on hardwood, as with so many other wings of society, there will be few fond farewells to 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 2 Cleveland Police Officers Avoid Federal Charges in Killing of Tamir Rice
description: Finding a lack of evidence to prosecute, the Justice Department ended a five-year inquiry into the death of the 12-year-old Black boy, who had been carrying a pellet gun when an officer shot him.
content: Two Cleveland police officers will avoid federal criminal charges for their role in the killing of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old Black boy who had been carrying a pellet gun when he was shot in 2014, the Justice Department announced on Tuesday, citing a lack of evidence in the high-profile case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: When Is a Comedy Special Also a Corporate Synergy Message?
description: Two year-end shows from Amazon and Netflix deliver some laughs, yes, but also serve as veiled ads for the streaming services themselves.
content: At the start of “Death to 2020,” a reporter played by Samuel L. Jackson sits alone in an abandoned office listening to a disembodied voice explain he’s looking back at the past year. “Why would you want to do that?” Jackson responds, with an additional curse for emphasis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips, Jesse Green and Laura Collins-Hughes
title: In Four Audio Plays, No Stages but Lots of New Voices
description: A big-box store, a hotel for transgender women and a dinner party gone awry are some of the places your ears will take you to.
content: When actors can’t gather onstage, they can still make drama with their voices. Our critics review four recent audio plays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Corum and Carl Zimmer
title: How the Novavax Vaccine Works
description: Using a coronavirus protein to train the immune system.
content: Using a coronavirus protein to train the immune system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning newsletter
title: The Great News Quiz of 2020
description: It’s been a newsy year. As 2020 comes to a close, how well do you remember it all?
content: It’s been a newsy year. As 2020 comes to a close, how well do you remember it all?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Miller
title: How to Celebrate New Year’s Eve With Kids
description: After nearly 10 months of sheltering in place, you might be out of ideas for a fun family night at home. Here’s how to get the party started.
content: After nearly 10 months of sheltering in place, you might be out of ideas for a fun family night at home. Here’s how to get the party started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By
title: What’s in Our Queue? Lynette Yiadom-Boakye’s Art
description: I’m a senior staff editor on the Culture desk, based in London. Here are five things I've been reading and listening to.
content: I’m a senior staff editor on the Culture desk, based in London. Here are five things I've been reading and listening to.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Year’s Resolutions for the Planet
description: Here are some ideas you wonderful readers sent to us.
content: Here are some ideas you wonderful readers sent to us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Corum and Carl Zimmer
title: How the Sinopharm Vaccine Works
description: Using inactivated coronaviruses to train the immune system.
content: Using inactivated coronaviruses to train the immune system.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The State of the Virus: 2020 in Review
description: How the coronavirus spread across the United States.
content: How the coronavirus spread across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $3 Million
description: A three-bedroom home with a guest cottage in Key West, an 18th-century Dutch Colonial in Brooklyn and a Federal-style townhouse in Alexandria.
content: A three-bedroom home with a guest cottage in Key West, an 18th-century Dutch Colonial in Brooklyn and a Federal-style townhouse in Alexandria.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Views for Miles in Costa Rica
description: This mountainside home in Costa Rica, built to maximize views of the Pacific Ocean, is on the market for $1.15 million.
content: This mountainside home in Costa Rica, built to maximize views of the Pacific Ocean, is on the market for $1.15 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Wood-Ridge, N.J.
description: This unpretentious suburb in Bergen County offers residents comfortable proximity to Manhattan and reasonably priced homes (some with skyline views).
content: This unpretentious suburb in Bergen County offers residents comfortable proximity to Manhattan and reasonably priced homes (some with skyline views).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Colorado May Have Second Case of Coronavirus Variant
description: The newly discovered and more contagious variant of the coronavirus, which was first seen in Britain, may have been found in a second person in Colorado after the state and health officials reported its first known case on Tuesday.
content: The newly discovered and more contagious variant of the coronavirus, which was first seen in Britain, may have been found in a second person in Colorado after the state and health officials reported its first known case on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Office Of The California Governor
title: California Will Offer Financial Incentives to Reopen School Districts
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California unveiled a $2 billion plan on Wednesday aimed at getting elementary school students back in the classroom safely starting in February, creating incentives of at least $450 per student to a phased-in reopening of classrooms for those who want to return.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California unveiled a $2 billion plan on Wednesday aimed at getting elementary school students back in the classroom safely starting in February, creating incentives of at least $450 per student to a phased-in reopening of classrooms for those who want to return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Amazon Buys Wondery as Podcasting Race Continues
description: The deal, valued at $300 million, is the latest in a string of acquisitions as streaming platforms expand beyond music and video.
content: Amazon is acquiring Wondery, the company behind podcasts such as “Dirty John,” “Dr. Death” and “The Shrink Next Door,” as the race to grab parts of the audio market continues.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 30, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 30, 2020.
content: An article on Tuesday about challenges faced by Nashville in 2020 misidentified one of the Nashville restaurants run by Trey Cioccia. It is the Farm House, not the Treehouse.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Finding Solace in Hiking
description: A reader considers it a lifeline in dealing with the stresses of today. Also: Do politicians need a college degree?

title: Vaccination Challenges, in the U.S. and Abroad
